title: Woman’s finger turns black after mistakenly injecting smallpox vaccine
text:
The woman’s finger after 57 days

An American lab worker’s finger began to rot after she accidentally injected herself with a smallpox-like virus – having turned down a vaccine before beginning an experiment.

The unidentified woman, 26, mistakenly jabbed herself with a needle in December 2018 when she was meant to be injecting mice with vaccinia virus.

She was taken to A&E having rinsed her finger for 15 minutes after the accident, but around 10 days later an itchy green blister had formed on the tip of her finger and she developed a fever.

Slowly the entire end of her finger turned black as if it was rotting away.

Spots of red were still prominent some 60 days after the mishap, with dead skin building up around the area.

The woman has since recovered from the traumatic incident but said she was forced to take more than three months off work while her finger healed.

By day 94 the finger was still not fully healed

According to an account in the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report journal, the woman from San Diego, US, became ill on day 12 of the trial, when doctors gave her one dose of ‘vaccinia immune globulin’, made from the antibodies of people who are already vaccinated.

She was also given the drug tecovirimat for a fortnight, along with antibiotics, to prevent the wound becoming infected.

Within two days of treatment, the woman’s fever vanished and the pain and swelling had mostly subsided.

In an unexpected upside, that means it is the first time that doctors have used tecovirimat – which has recently been approved to treat smallpox in the USA – to treat a laboratory-acquired vaccinia virus infection.

The tip of her finger developed a deep black patch – this was the wound on day 25

Vaccinia virus is less serious than smallpox – known as variola virus – but is used to make the vaccine for it.

The woman declined to have the vaccine initially because she did not ‘appreciate the extent of infection that could occur’, the report said.

Smallpox killed hundreds of millions of people but has now been eradicated, with the last death in Britain that of Janet Parker, recorded in 1978.
